title: Puerto Rico residents concerned over failing dam
description:
(23 Sep 2017) Puerto Rican authorities have evacuated as many as 70,000 people who are downstream of a failing dam, displacing residents from the potential path of a massive flood should the dam collapse.
More than 15 inches (38 centimetres) of rain fell on the mountains surrounding the Guajataca Dam in northwest Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria left the island Wednesday afternoon, swelling the reservoir behind the nearly 90-year-old dam.
Ruth Doris Feliciano Hernandez left her home near the reservoir Friday with her 95-year-old mother, who needs oxygen to survive. 
Hernandez, overcome with emotion, told how her neighbours were in a panic after authorities came and advised everyone to leave. 
She returned to her home Saturday, and says she plans to stay in spite of the threat from the dam collapsing.
Water from the bursting reservoir behind the dam partially collapsed a bridge leading across a river below it, and damaged the roadway running alongside the hillside above the river. 
Roaring water cascaded through the partially collapsed spillway of the dam, sending plumes of vapor high into the air as it churned into the river below.
Some residents returned to their homes Saturday as the water levels in the reservoir began to sink to lower levels. 
But it's unclear if the water release has mitigated the threat of a dam collapse.
Maria Nieves, a homeowner who lives adjacent to the reservoir, says she and her family came back to her flooded street, and now plan to stay because they have nowhere else to go.
Authorities launched an evacuation of tens of thousands of people living downstream, sending buses to move people away and sending frantic warnings on Twitter that went unseen by many in the blacked-out coastal area.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/32d6184153a2a5fe414c7c4709377b33 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
